form.label: Bucket Count vs. Maximum Count
form.searchTemplate: `fb_data_from_today` state="hot" OR state="warm" `_fb_summary_recs($host$, $index$)` | bucket _time span=1d | eval state=mvappend(state, if(endEpoch>now(), "ballast", null())) | stats max(sizeOnDiskMB) AS sizeOnDiskMB by _time, path, index, state

html.div:
The family of views in the Retention menu is aimed at helping administrators visualize and thereby tune various retention parameters for their indexed data. General information about retention settings can be found in the Splunk documentation for version 6.0.x here.
This dashboard is focused on limits based upon the count of buckets within the index. Only buckets in the hot and warm states can be limited by count.
Within the Warm Buckets panel, three quantities are shown. The first is the current count of buckets in this state. The second, labeled "Ballast" represents the counts of buckets which have time stamps in the future. These buckets may not pass through the bucket lifecyle in a normal way. The third value shown within this panel is the current limit, as provided in indexes.conf.
The chart below, titled Usage vs. Configured Maximum Count (Hot / Warm Only), shows "Count:" and "Limit:" values over the hot and warm states. If there are ballast buckets, a count of these will be shown as well.

input.label: Host
input.populatingSearch: | inputlookup fb_hostname_index_cache | dedup orig_host | sort orig_host

input.label: Index
input.populatingSearch: | inputlookup fb_hostname_index_cache | search orig_host=$host$ | dedup orig_index | sort orig_index

single.searchPostProcess: search state="ballast" | stats count, sum(count) AS ballast

chart.title: Usage vs. Configured Maximum Count (Hot / Warm Only)
chart.searchString: state="hot" OR state="warm" `_fb_summary_recs($host$, $index$)` | bucket _time span=1d | eval state=mvappend(state, if(endEpoch>now(), "ballast", null())) | stats max(sizeOnDiskMB) AS sizeOnDiskMB by _time, path, index, state | join type=left index [ | `_fb_rest_index_config($host$, $index$)` ] | eval limit=if(state=="hot", maxHotBuckets, if(state=="warm", maxWarmDBCount, 0)) | timechart span=1d dc(path) AS "Count", first(limit) AS Limit by state | rename comment AS "Just in case..." | fields - "Limit: ballast"
